title: Problem-based learning approach to developing consciousness-level assessment apps

context.prior_knowledge: Basic Mobile App Usage Experience and Intermediate-Level Mathematical Concepts
context.additional_context: A process for pre-service teachers to develop mathematical problem-solving skills while experiencing an educational app development process applicable to real-world medical education contexts

learning_goals: Learners can design two or more core features of a consciousness-level assessment app by applying problem-based learning (PBL) methodologies.

Within one week, learners develop a prototype (minimum 2 scales implemented) that converts the three Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) items (motor function, verbal response, eye-opening) into a digital evaluation system using mathematical modeling techniques (e.g., regression analysis, weighted scoring) and submit results meeting four or more of the five peer evaluation rubric items.

Within one week, teams of 3–4 members select two instructional design tasks on user interface optimization, proceed through a three-stage process (problem definition → solution development → prototype implementation), and submit a final report and demo video.

resources: Low-Code App Development Platform (e.g., MIT App Inventor)

difficulty: Easy - Simple structure with minimal constraints
